Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: The phone in my hand feels heavier than usual as I dial another number, my headset pressing into my temples. It’s the last day of the quarter, and the manager’s voice still echoes in my mind: “We need every sale to hit target—no exceptions.” My bonus, and maybe even my job, hangs in the balance. But my thoughts keep drifting to the election. I realized this morning that my ID is at home, and today is the only window I have to get it before the polls close tomorrow. If I leave now, I’ll miss the team’s final push, but if I stay, I might lose my chance to vote. My colleagues’ voices rise around me, urging each other on, while my own conscience nags at me about my civic duty. I stare at the clock, feeling the pressure from both sides, my heart pounding as I weigh the expectations of my job against my responsibility as a voter.
